comments:
Sometimes I get this stack trace at the end of the JUnit tests:

org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.AssertionFailedException: assertion failed:
The application has not been initialized.
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.Assert.isTrue(Assert.java:107)
	at
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.assertInitialized(InternalPlatform.java:218)
	at
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.log(InternalPlatform.java:822)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.ImplicitJobs.endJob(ImplicitJobs.java:128)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.WorkerPool.endJob(WorkerPool.java:96)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:83)
*** Bug 91337 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
This is caused by trying to log an error after the platform has shutdown. John?

I won't log anything in this case. The plan is to log situations where jobs are
still running when runtime shuts down. People shouldn't be leaving jobs or
threads running after their own plugins have shutdown.
Is it possible to know what jobs are running?

I'm going to add more debugging when there are jobs still running at shutdown. 
Right now there is no way to tell from the stack trace what job was running.  If
it's easy to reproduce, you could see what job is running by catching the
AssertionFailedException.
*** Bug 91391 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I have released fixes for this exception and for the exception in bug 91391. 
Errors will be printed to System.err when the platform has already shut down. 
The real bug is that a job is still running at that point.  I have added
instrumentation to report warnings in the log file for any job that is still
running when the platform has shut down.  If you re-run your tests with latest
runtime+resources from head, you should see the culprit that was causing these
exceptions.

traces.message: assertion failed: The application has not been initialized.
